channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Republicans and Democrats are at a standstill as government barrels toward shut down
item.description: The government will shut down at midnight tonight if Congress can't reach a deal. But Republicans and Democrats are at a standstill, each refusing to give in to the other's demands.

item.title: Sen. Elizabeth Warren talks about the potential for a government shutdown
item.description: Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., talks about the potential government shutdown, what congressional Democrats are demanding and whether she thinks President Trump will carry out his layoff threat.

item.title: Illinois governor says Trump's military deployment threat isn't about safety
item.description: Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker says President Trump's threat to deploy 100 military personnel to Chicago is an effort to cause "mayhem," not make residents safer.

item.title: South Dakota Rep. Dusty Johnson talks about the possibility of a government shutdown
item.description: NPR speaks with Rep. Dusty Johnson, R-S.D., about the impasse over the budget and the possibility of a government shutdown Wednesday.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The government will shut down at 12:01 a.m. Wednesday if Congress can't reach a deal, reactions to President Trump's plan to end the war in Gaza, Trump and Hegseth to meet with top military officials.

item.title: Before U.S. visitor visa ban for Palestinians, one changed this young woman's life
item.description: Before the U.S. suspended visitor visas for Palestinians in August, one helped change a young woman's life. NPR speaks to her and the American surgeon who saved her leg.

item.title: 'There's been a lot of tears': Local public media stations grapple with federal cuts
item.description: Federal funding cuts to public media go into effect Wednesday. A South Dakota station explains what it's had to do as local stations across the country adjust to the loss.

item.title: Video game publisher Electronic Arts going private in a deal valued at $55 billion
item.description: Electronic Arts, the video game publisher behind titles like "Madden NFL" and "The Sims," says it has agreed to be acquired by a group of investors in a deal worth $55 billion.

item.title: Taylor Swift's speaking voice has evolved alongside her music eras, study finds
item.description: Taylor Swift talks about her music in terms of eras. A new University of Michigan study found the way she speaks has also changed over the course of her career.

item.title: Federal workers who took Trump's buyout get final paychecks and an uncertain future
item.description: Federal workers who took the Trump administration's buyout offer come off the payroll at the end of September. Now some are confronting fear, regret and uncertainty as they figure out what's next.
